content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two large fragments of tissue, predominantly composed of adipose tissue. Within the fat, there are multiple large, irregular, and confluent nodules of pale, basophilic material. This appearance is highly suggestive of extensive pools of extracellular mucin, characteristic of a mucinous adenocarcinoma that has infiltrated the pericolic fat. It is difficult to identify distinct lymph node structures at this low magnification, as they may be completely replaced by the mucinous tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The low-power view is highly suspicious for mucinous adenocarcinoma. My primary goal is to confirm the presence of malignant cells within these mucin pools to correctly stage the tumor. The area marked by the green box is a representative section of these mucinous nodules. I am zooming in to carefully inspect for any floating tumor cells, small cell clusters, or even 'ghost cells' within the mucin. Distinguishing between acellular mucin (which can be part of a host response) and mucin containing tumor cells is critical for determining if this represents a tumor deposit (pN1c) or a completely replaced lymph node (pN1/2), which directly impacts the patient's staging and treatment. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically scan all the submitted adipose tissue to find lymph nodes or tumor deposits. The area marked by the green box is located within a fibrous band separating fat lobules. This area may have appeared slightly more cellular or texturally different from the surrounding simple fat at low power. It is crucial to examine such areas at high magnification to rule out the presence of small clusters of tumor cells (tumor deposit/satellite nodule), lymphatic invasion, or a very small, subtle, or completely replaced lymph node. The goal is to investigate any area that is not clearly benign fat or simple fibrous tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is at the periphery of the main mucinous deposits. While much of the tissue appears to be acellular mucin at low power, the area in the green box appears slightly more structured and basophilic. A pathologist must meticulously search for the cellular component of the tumor (malignant glands or single cells) which are often found at the interface between mucin pools and the surrounding stroma or fat. This area represents a region of interest to confirm the presence of viable tumor cells, which is crucial for diagnosis and staging, or to identify if this is a remnant of a lymph node being replaced by the tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the presence of large pools of pale, amorphous, and largely acellular extracellular mucin. These pools are separated by thin, pink, fibrous septa. Within the mucin, there are very rare, scattered cells with pyknotic (shrunken, dark) nuclei and some cellular debris, often referred to as 'ghost cells'. There are no well-formed glands or definitive viable tumor cell clusters in this specific field. My impression is that this is an area of mucinous adenocarcinoma with very low cellularity. In the context of a primary colorectal mucinous adenocarcinoma, finding such a deposit of extracellular mucin in the pericolic fat, even if acellular, is considered a tumor deposit and is significant for staging.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see mature adipose tissue composed of large adipocytes with single, peripherally pushed nuclei. Interspersed within the fat are broad bands of paucicellular, eosinophilic, fibrous connective tissue (stroma). Within this stroma, there are scattered spindle cells, consistent with fibroblasts, and a few small, dark, round cells, likely lymphocytes, indicating mild chronic inflammation. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is benign fibroadipose tissue with reactive fibrous changes. There is no evidence of malignancy in this field of view.
This is ROI 3. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see large pools of extracellular mucin, which appears as a basophilic, stringy, and acellular material. This mucin is dissecting through mature adipose tissue and is surrounded by thin fibrous septa. Importantly, within this specific field of view, there are no definite malignant epithelial cells or glandular structures identifiable within the mucin pools. My impression is of acellular mucin dissecting through adipose tissue. This finding is highly suggestive of mucinous adenocarcinoma, but it could represent a complete response to neoadjuvant therapy (treatment effect) if only acellular mucin is found throughout the specimen. The search must continue across the entire slide to find any viable residual cancer cells to confirm active disease.
